raw_text: Culotta et al (2007) present a system which uses an on line learning approach to train a classifier to judge whether two entities are co referential or not
clean_text: Culotta et al (2007) present a system which uses an online learning approach to train a classifier to judge whether two entities are coreferential or not.

clean_text: In our study, we also tested the "Most-X" strategy for the first-order features as in (Culotta et al., 2007), but got similar results without much difference (±0.5% F-measure) in performance.

raw_text: The one exception is the size of a cluster (Culotta et al, 2007)
clean_text: The one exception is the size of a cluster (Culotta et al, 2007).

raw_text: Culotta et al (2007) also apply on line learning in a first-order logic frame work that enables non-local features, though using a greedy search algorithm. Latent antecedents
clean_text: Culotta et al (2007) also apply online learning in a first-order logic framework that enables non-local features, though using a greedy search algorithm.

raw_text: Culotta et al (2007) introduce a first-order probabilistic model which implements features over sets of mentions and thus operates directly on entities
clean_text: Culotta et al (2007) introduce a first-order probabilistic model which implements features over sets of mentions and thus operates directly on entities.

raw_text: However, with the advent of the ACE data, many systems either evaluated only true mentions ,i.e. mentions which are included in the annotation, the so-called key, or even received true information for mention boundaries, heads of mentions and mention type (Culotta et al, 2007, inter alia)
clean_text: However, with the advent of the ACE data, many systems either evaluated only true mentions, i.e. mentions which are included in the annotation, the so-called key, or even received true information for mention boundaries, heads of mentions and mention type (Culotta et al, 2007, inter alia).

raw_text: Culotta et al (2007) introduce a first-order probabilistic model which implements features over sets of mentions
clean_text: Culotta et al (2007) introduce a first-order probabilistic model which implements features over sets of mentions.

raw_text: Most previous attempts to solve the co reference resolution task globally have been hampered by employing a local pairwise model in the classification step (step 1) while only the clustering step realizes a global approach ,e.g. Luo et al (2004), Nicolae& amp; Nicolae (2006), Klenner (2007), Denis& amp; Baldridge (2009), lesser so Culotta et al (2007)

As we show, this combination of a pairwise model and strong features produces a 1.5 percent 294age point increase in B-Cubed F-Score over a complex model in the state-of-the-art system by Culotta et al (2007), although their system uses a complex, non-pairwise model, computing features over partial clusters of mentions
clean_text: As we show, this combination of a pairwise model and strong features produces a 1.5 percentage point increase in B-Cubed F-Score over a complex model in the state-of-the-art system by Culotta et al. (2007), although their system uses a complex, non-pairwise model, computing features over partial clusters of mentions.

raw_text: Our model differs from that of Ng and Cardie in that we impose the constraint that non-pronouns can not refer back to pronouns, and in that we use as training examples all ordered pairs of mentions, subject to the constraint above. Culotta et al (2007) introduced a model that predicts whether a pair of equivalence classes should bemerged, using features computed over all the mentions in both classes
clean_text: Culotta et al (2007) introduced a model that predicts whether a pair of equivalence classes should be merged, using features computed over all the mentions in both classes.

raw_text: For our experiments in Section 5, we use gold mention types as is done by Culotta et al (2007) and Luo and Zitouni (2005) .Note that in the experiments described in Section 6 we predict the mention types as described there and do not use any gold data
clean_text: For our experiments in Section 5, we use gold mention types as is done by Culotta et al (2007) and Luo and Zitouni (2005).

raw_text: Many of our features are similar to those described in Culotta et al (2007)
clean_text: Many of our features are similar to those described in Culotta et al (2007).

raw_text: Our test set contains the same 107 documents as Culotta et al (2007) .Our training set is a random 80% of the 336 documents in their training set and our Dev set is the remaining 20%
clean_text: Our test set contains the same 107 documents as Culotta et al (2007).

raw_text: For the experiments in Section 5, following Culottaet al (2007), to make experiments more comparable across systems, we assume that perfect mention boundaries and mention type labels are given
clean_text: For the experiments in Section 5, following Culotta et al (2007), to make experiments more comparable across systems, we assume that perfect mention boundaries and mention type labels are given.

raw_text: Culotta et al (2007) is the best comparable system of which we are aware
clean_text: Culotta et al (2007) is the best comparable system of which we are aware.

raw_text: Note that since we report results on Dev-Eval, the results in Table 6 are not directly comparable with Culotta et al (2007)
clean_text: Note that since we report results on Dev-Eval, the results in Table 6 are not directly comparable with Culotta et al (2007).

raw_text: Each instance consists of features that are computed based solely on NPk as well as cluster-level features, which describe the relationship between cj and NPk. Motivated in part by Culotta et al (2007), we create cluster-level features from the relational features inour feature set using four predicates: NONE, MOST FALSE, MOST-TRUE, and ALL
clean_text: Motivated in part by Culotta et al (2007), we create cluster-level features from the relational features in our feature set using four predicates: NONE, MOST FALSE, MOST-TRUE, and ALL.

raw_text: A04CU: Train/dev/test split of the newswire portion of the ACE 2004 training set7 utilized in Culotta et al (2007), Bengston and Roth (2008) and Stoyanov et al (2009)
